subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized and Theories overlaps
msgSnippet: [+CC: Charlie Poole, who might be interested in the example...] Joakim is correct.  A theory promises that correct code will pass the theory for any parameters
messageBody:
[+CC: Charlie Poole, who might be interested in the example...]

Joakim is correct. A theory promises that correct code will pass the
theory for any parameters you pass in:

@Theory public void additionIsCommutative(int x, int y) {
assertEquals(x + y, y + x);
}

A "Parameterized test" is what I like to call an "answer key". It can
be applied to some different parameters, but you have to look at the
key to know which are correct. If we converted the Parameterized
Runner to behave more like theories, it might look like (totally
making this up):

// Read top to bottom
@Answers("a") public int[] = {3, 4, 5}
@Answers("b") public int[] = {4, 3, 12}
@Answers("c") public int[] = {5, 5, 13}

@AnswerKey public void pythogoreanTheorem(int a, int b, int c) {
assertEquals(c, hypoteneuse(a, b));
}

The Theories interface currently looks different than the
Parameterized interface because experience with the Parameterized
Runner made me dissatisfied with the interface.

Hope this helps,

David Saff

Not every value of a, b, and c should make this test pass.

On Sun, Oct 19, 2008 at 6:34 PM, Joakim Ohlrogge
<joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
> The difference as far as I understand it is that theories make a
> promise that the theory will pass with anything you can pass in as
> parameters (minus any assumptions you make with assumeThat or
> similar). That makes it possible, in theory :), to generate data for
> theories and find holes in them (parameters where they don't pass).
>
> A theory could be something like:
>
> @Theory
> public void
> sortingAlgoritmsProduceResultsOfTheSameLengthAsTheInput(SortingAlgorithm
> algorithm, List input) {
> assertThat(algorithm.sort(input).length(), is(input.length));
> }
>
> Regardless which sorting algorithm you use and which input you throw
> at it the result should have the same length as the input.
>
> Parameterized tests make no such claim. They will pass for the data
> that is setup in the test but may or may not fail with other data.
>
> Whether parameterized tests will stay or go... I don't know.
>
> Hope this helps
> /J
>
